sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated June 27, 1893
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Harden thanks Schenker for an article on Smetana; encourages him to write on the Viennese appetite for Italian operas; and sends greetings to [Adolph?] Gelber.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Harden, Maximilian; Schenker, Heinrich; realism; Vienna; Sonzogno market; Smetana; Gelber, Adolph?

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated June 27, 1893

tei:transcription.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] Deutsche Reichspost Postkarte
An Herrn Dr. H. Schenker in Wien III Wohnung Fraungasse 1
{verso} [printed header with handwritten date inserted] HERAUSGEBER: [–] BERLIN W. 9. 27.6 93 MAXIMILIAN HARDEN [–] DIE ZUKUNFT [–] 27 KÖTHENER STRASSE. [decorated printed rule]

ein kl. Ueberblick—ohne Realismus That is, without a discussion of Realism.—über den Sonzogno-Markt This would eventually become “Der Sonzogno-Markt in Wien,” which appeared in Die Zukunft on August 5, 1893. In that article, Schenker critiques the consequences of the Viennese market for Italian operas largely subvented by the Italian publishing house Sonzogno: “We deserve, quite candidly, everything unpleasant that Sonzogno and Ricordi may yet visit on us in the future, since we are paying the price for abandoning the great prophets of our own art.” („[W]ir verdienen wohl redlich alles Uebel, das Sonzogno und Ricordi in Zukunft uns noch bescheren mögen, da wir den Abfall von den großen Propheten unserer eigenen Kunst büßen.“ Heinrich Schenker, “Der Sonzogno-Markt in Wien,” in Hellmut Federhofer, Heinrich Schenker als Essayist und Kritiker (Hildesheim: Georg Olms Verlag, 1990), p. 55.] wird mir sehr willkommen sein. Den Smetana| This article, “Friedrich Smetana,” was published in Die Zukunft on July 1, 1893. It is reprinted in Hellmut Federhofer, Heinrich Schenker als Essayist und Kritiker (Hildesheim: Georg Olms Verlag, 1990), pp. 48-53. fand ich vortrefflich. Besten Dank! Grüßen Sie mir Gelber, Probably the scholar of German language and literature, Adolph Gelber (1856-1923). der nicht kam u. nicht schreibt.
Mit bestem Gruß, in wilder Hast Ihr [signed:] H.

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated June 27, 1893

tei:translation.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] German Imperial Post Postcard
To Dr. H. Schenker in Vienna III Address Fraungasse 1
{verso} [printed header with handwritten date inserted] EDITOR: [–] BERLIN W. 9. June 27, 93 MAXIMILIAN HARDEN [–] DIE ZUKUNFT [–] 27 KÖTHENER STRASSE. [decorated printed rule]
A brief overview—without Realism—of the Sonzogno market would be very welcome. I found the Smetana splendid. Many thanks! Send greetings for me to Gelber, who didn’t come and isn’t writing.
With best wishes, in wild haste, Yours, [signed:] H.
